29417122.review:
[h1] Wonderful Game [/h1]

It has a lot of character and it looks as though a great deal of thought was put into every aspect of it. Even the beastiary leaves you with a smirk after seing the illustrations.

I will say though that the game feels built more for controllers. M+kb navigation of menues can be irritating at times. 

Given its current state I still can boast that it is more than worth the 15 USD price tag and honestly in hindsight I would have paid twice that. It already has over 1000 items and 100 quests leaving so much to be discovered beneath the surface. The one main drawback is the fact is only has a few story missions [b] currently [/b]. 

[h1] Items [/h1]

Currently items of the same type act uniformly aside from elemental damage and resistance. There are a couple items that have interesting effects like slow and knockback but generally you are choosing between lightwight with high damage/movement/dodge or heavy that are more survivable. The non human characters have less customization but I have yet to see an item that I felt was not thoughtfully made and memorable. 

[h1] Quests [/h1]

The quests are absolutely bonkers. There are some delivery missions and find this missions but even something you would intitially dismiss in other games turns out to be comedic. For instance [spoiler] in one side quest you find a lizard and are tasked with taking it to its owner. The owner immediatly says he is going to eat it when you find him. You find out the lizard is sentient and blows up his owner telepathically. [/spoiler] 

[h1] Characters  [/h1]

All of the characters names are procedurally generated with a huge pool to choose from. There are a decent amount of types of enemies and even the worst of them is still viable with the right team. There is some balanceing that needs to be done still. One of the ways they balance currently is by making larger units take up more space on your roster. For example you have 6 slots after unlocking the final ones with in game currency. These can be filled in the following ways.

Huge Unit = 3 slots
Large Unit = 2 slots
Regular Unit = 1 slots
Pair of Small Units = 1 slot
Some units can spawn up to 6 spawn units during each fight.

In this way a 2v2 arena fight could theoretically have 8 entities on the field or 84. 
[spoiler] 8 massive troll moms without thier spawn/ 12 gorgons and up to 72 spawn [/spoiler]

[h1] Difficulty  [/h1]

Overall the game is not incredibly difficult after learning the basics but with the inclusion of Insane mode and elite enemies you will be pulling your hair out.

[h1] Conclusion  [/h1]

Remembering that this is an early access game and everything is subject to change, I give it a perfect 5/7 stars. 

[h1] Look forward to seeing you in the PIT.  [/h1]

29416843.review:
The Behemoth is back!

I've been a huge fan of this studio since Newgrounds, have played everything they have developed up to this point, and I have to say that Pit People is turning out to be one of the best efforts they have ever made. Castle Crashers was amazing for unlocks and playing through multiple times to find all of the nuances and secrets lying underneath, but after 30-40 hours you have done and seen most of what the game has to offer. Pit People is so different in that aspect, as there are literally 1,000+ items to unlock, a multitude of different characters and species to "recruit", and a billion reasons to sink your time into this game.

As Early Access, the game gives you a very limited view of what is in store for the main story experience, but it vastly makes up for this with an addictive but accessible PVP and super-hard Co-Op pit mode. Not to mention the huge open world that seems to have a lot to discover, and plenty of creatures to add to your team as mentioned before.

There are a few noticable and jarring UI problems with this game. For one, a lot of the stat management and overviews for characters are incredibly subtle. At first, I had no idea that leveling your recruits mattered. There's no representation of your stats growing or what the growth per individual species would be. You'll especially notice this once you recruit a Mascot species type, as their attack damage on the stats page reads a huge number above all other species, but they merely buff other characters and don't do the damage stated on their page. There needs to be more ways to differenciate between the different Clops or Humans you recruit, as well as stat comparison to someone you're wanting to swap in on your team before taking on PvP or the World Map. 

The UI is also very difficult to manage with a mouse + keyboard. I have been playing most of this game with the Steam Controller, and I find that method of play to be a lot more enjoyable. Playing on my laptop with a mouse and keyboard, or even my main PC, was a challenge. There's no visual feedback when you're nearing the edge of the screen in the main hub for bulding selections other than a "click your mouse" prompt, and you usually find yourself running between buildings often trying to make a simple selection. There are plenty of other examples of the UI being incredibly clunky and vague, like the Quest Selection page before you depart to the world. I had to take a few moments to grasp what they wanted me to do.

I've put a good amount of hours into this game so far, and I cannot wait to see what they bring to the table with it. Definitely one of the better Early Access titles I have ever played. I see this game having such potential for updates, maybe little DLC packs for new character stories or mission packs. Hell, maybe even release these quarterly for free. I can also see a potential competitive scene emerging from this game once all the balancing has been ironed out, and most of the gameplay has been tweaked a bit.

I will update this review when the game goes live, but I would highly recommend you buy this if you are on the fence about it. I would say 80% of the game is there, and what is included is well worth the $15 asking price.

To the Pits!

I'm reviewing this game in it's current state, and so far, I've had alot of fun with Pit People. The humor is perfect, and the art is fantastic. There are so many different weapons and units to delve into and figure out; However, this is part of the problem. The game throws you in with a minimal tutorial and trying to figure out the game can be quite overwhelming.

My first complaint is the way the team customization menu is set up. When trying to choose new swords or helmets for my characters, I often feel its very clunky and uninformative, and the lack of individual statistics for each piece of equipment, trying to figure out the balance of the game is hell. There is also no point in really equiping a sword over a mace because mace's can bash helmets. Swords cant and they both deal around the same damage.

My second complaint is the different races and what they're good against and weak against. It simply gives symbols without telling me what exactly those symbols mean. I wish there was more direction in what these mean and more explanation in the Surival Journal. Traveling around the map seems like a mess because I see all these monuments that I just discovered, but it's just very confusing and nothing is truly recognizable. Unlike in Castle Crashers where there were different and recognizable districts with different enemies. 29412804.review:
[b]The Behemoth strikes again![/b] And in all the right places.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Combat is incredibly fun and has a lot of depth.

[*]There’s quite a lot of customization.

[*]The story is pure comedy gold and the narrator is as outstanding as ever.

[*]Tons upon tons of side-quests, types of units, items, generally stuff to find and do.

[*]The Pit. An arena located in the city of Pit People. It’s the place where you go for some challenging co-op or pvp.

[*]The soundtrack is again in the amazingly light-hearted Behemoth style.

[*]The art style is as fantastic as always.

[*]The characters are amazing, and the dialog is hilarious. Regardless if we’re talking about random npcs or story characters.

[*]The world map is somewhat procedural, large and fun to explore.

[*]Full Co-Op and multiplayer support, be it for the main quests, side quests and The Pit.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[*]The main quest was very short so far. This is in EA, but considering they said that the Story included is a “sizable chunk” is kind of worrying. 

[*]The game doesn’t give you an awful lot of useful information (e.g. I get a random buff/nerf or effect from a weapon, but there’s no way to see what it is; enemy health in numbers etc.)

[*]There’s a lot of items however most of which are purely cosmetic, while others have various combat stats. I wish more of the items had direct effects over stats, even if it’s only a difference in numbers.

29412010.review:
This game is interesting. . .an I wish I could say that is a good thing. While this game is Early Access, it is not riddled with bugs that create huge problems. I believe it is more of a feature skinny Early Access, and the way the game is, the coding should not be difficult, and a below average dev woul be able to create it without gamebreaking bugs, so that is not a big shock. To me, the game is very boring, too slow, and doesnt bring anything new to the tactics based RPG. I actually think it takes away a lot of things that make for a good tactical RPG. 

 The equipment diversiity is made in a way that they are only for looks. Getting new weapons and whatnot, just change what they look like, but all swords do the same thing, and all bows and so forth. I hate this, and really think it detracts from the replayability of a game like this. Games like Final Fantasy Tactics did this genre so well, and other games go and create something similar, remove some things, and change some things and add some things, but devs seem to constantly change the WRONG things, and make for a worse playing experience than what would otherwise be here.

ALL that being said, this game is NOT bad, and is actually something that could be worth playing, if it were priced right. This is $5 game, when completed. Right now it should be on sale for $3 or $4, and never be more than $5 when done. Unfortunately devs don't know how to price games, and think their game is worth more than it is. Selling 1000 copies at $15, is far worse than selling 10000 copies at $5, and everything about this game screams under $10 game. Dev really needs to look at other games on Steam, and really decide how much this game should be priced at. 

Don't support this project at this price point, I beleive you will be wasting your money, and won't be happy with your purchase.

29409567.review:
To see the game in action and our thoughts, check out [b]Catalysts Gaming’s Let’s Play[/b]:
https://youtu.be/rVbyRKzUYLw
As a turn-based adventure game, Pit People greatly differs from The Behemoth’s beat-em ups Alien Hominid and Castle Crashers and puzzle platformer BattleBlock Theater. As with these games, though, the patented wacky Behemoth humor is definitely present and possibly at its best, with silliness around every corner, craziness that will leave you confused yet smiling like an idiot, and references to past games hidden (or not so much) in every nook and cranny. Stamper as the voice of an omnipresent narrator is particularly on cue with his side-splitting spiteful commentary and nefarious interactions with the game characters and world that can happen at seemingly unexpected moments as he looks to kill his boredom at your expense.

For being in Early Access, the game looks and plays great, with solid controls and crisp, styled 2D sprites, though some of the UI could perhaps be cleaned up a bit or better explained. Your house in town where you can change out your team initially felt a bit overwhelming, requiring a lot of clicks to change out equipment and lack of button cues leading to a team member almost getting sold. Likewise, we received no warning that a quest would receive an F for Failure by returning back to town before we completed it, leading to an awkward visit with the local principal. Battles, meanwhile, could begin to get cluttered and claustrophobic, especially with the extra bodies and input in co-op, with allies and enemies having similar color and designs bunched up together on screen at once; there was often confusion on which character was currently selected and who was moving where. Our gripes are minor compared to the refined edges, though, and once you get things down, battles can feel intuitive while still retaining strategic complexity, allowing fights to be as fast-paced or as slow and methodical as you wish them to be. With a discount while in Early Access, Pit People appears to be another great game by The Behemoth that is worth a pick up and play, and we are excited to see the rest of the crazy content and wacky adventure that will be in the finished game.

[u]Catalyst Players/Reviewers[/u]: Jacob and Murphy
[u]Version[/u]: [b]Early Access[/b] - Jan. 18, 2017
[u]Played[/u]: Co-Op Campaign (3hrs)

29400832.review:
READ THIS IN YOUR WILL STAMPER VOICE

I remember playing castle crasher back in 2010 and absolutely loving each and every bit of it, even going as far as to complete the game many times using the Dance Dance Revolution dance pad or Guitar Hero 2 controllers for hours on end,... Then I found out about alien hominid, and I absolutely loved that too (even though it was hard as all hell). When Battle Block theatre was announced I couldn't wait (but I had some how managed). Bought it the day it game out and enjoyed the living shit out of that game, the reason I didn't buy it on steam was that I managed to unlock nearly head for the prisoner. The second I found out about game number four (now Pit People) I shit bricks. I had just played through games like XCOM and Fire emblem (WaifuWars:Awakening) and really started to like the turn based strategy genre so I felt like fate had delivered the dream game. Little did I know that this dream game would also be early access. Mow lets get into the pros and cons (so far).

PROS
+The signiture Behemoth artstyle, the very reason I love the brush tool in Adobe Flash (By the time I typed Flash it 
  crashed)
+Wonderful soundtrack I walready wish I could buy.
+Lots of customization.
+Instead of moving units one by one they all move at once.
+A unique system of instead targetting an any, a charater will instead attack one enemy withen thier range prioritizing
  melee attacks over ranged attacks.
+A simple armor system.
+The randomly generated enemies and names (as far as I know though the character types and positions do not change 
  for scenarios which is awesome)
+The "class/races" as far as I can tell play pretty differently and uniquely. I couldn't imainge what game would have a 
  cupcake that mutilates itself to heal others, though its probably hidden somewhere in some DnD story.
+The humor. I'm always one for a good fart joke, but when voiced by Will Stamper, I love a good fart joke,
+Will stamper is the one voice that isn't in the parody of simish that the characters speak in. I love it.

CONS
-No name customization, though I do like the random names I wanna name a party after a few friends and I then place 
  bets on who dies in what order in the pit.
-The game explains how to play it, but not how the character building works which you kinda just learn on your own.
-Catchin- errr "recruiting" a unit always seems to give me two stars instead of three after each battle, but it makes sense 
  considering Will Stamper praises you for as murdering as many people in a turn as you can.
-Never seem to get a toon gold, but not too much of a con unless you really want to buy a 7K gold unit.
-Not enough content... yet.

For dedicated Behemoth fans you should buy this after reading this, it has a fairly short download time too so you won't die from getting hyped. 
For people who have played a Behemoth game I would wait a week or so then check on the updates.
For people who are interested in this you should wait a month, then check on the updates.

If Dan Palidan and Tom Fulp are reading this, thank you for work and time. I really hope you enjoy your work as much as I do. I really hope you guys flesh this game out. You already have 1,300+ ITEMS, each one unique and quirky! I don't know how you manage to do it but you guys really buckle some pants when it comes down to making video games. Keep at it!

29396788.review:
Pure excellence as is the usual with The Behemoth. The animation is wonderful, the art style awesome, the humor hilarious and off the wall, the gameplay is super solid, the story is so far, priceless. I love the narrator. The game does kind of fail to explain its self very well, luckily I'm familiar with turn based, grid based, rpg games. The fact that it IS LOCAL CO-OP, makes it awesome for me and the wife.  To be to the point, thus far it's a 8/10 easy. It could very well be as good as castle crashers in a lot of ways. We could have an award winner here.

PROS
-Great Behemoth style game just like Castle Crasher and Battle Block Theater.
-Wonderful humor/art style
-Solid turn based RPG gameplay, great animations
-Local Co-Op (as well as online, so far though it seems to be invite co-op only)
-Online Competitive play, if you're into that sorta... thing...
-Absolutely mind blowing soundtrack


CONS
-The tutorial is rather haphazard. While I slid right into playing, I didn't feel like how the game worked was very well explained, it just felt familiar enough to pick up and play.
-The quest system didn't seem to be explained at all, I didn't even realize I had "quests" outside of what the story narrative covered as the general 'story' quest. I didn't realize there were quests in a sort of quest log format that could be turned in for rewards until I saw my first quest complete pop up. 
- Your "Home base" i.e the town you return to during your adventures to rest and upgrade party members, gets randomly moved about every 3 returns to it or so. It is only ever moved when you are in it, so you don't have to worry about it moving while you're gone, but you can't really make any exploration progress this way because you're continously being moved to new places you don't know.
-You have a limit to the amount of loot you can carry, you must return to town to deposit your booty and then head back out. 
-Trading is not explained in co-op, at least not in local. When you return home in co-op you'll get a screen of loot between you and your partner, the left and right represent players 1 and 2 respectively. From the start nothing is 'selected', anything selected is automatically given to the other player. I say given, instead of trade, because if the other player doesn't select anything, they still get everything you clicked anyway for free. This isn't a problem, especially in co-op where maybe someone got something they don't need but the other does. The point is, what this screen even meant let alone how it worked, was not explained at all. 
-So far no luck match making. I'm not saying it doesn't work, I just am saying I've tried to find someone to do the Pit Co-Op with and gotten nothing three times over two days.

29388969.review: Another great game by The Behemoth, this game stays true to Castle Crashers and Battleblock Theatre by keeping the humor and charm of both. 29374457.review:
I am really enjoying the game! 

So I watched gameplay videos etc to get a sense of wether Pit People would be for me. I took a leap (with my credit card that's no unheard of) and I do not regret my decision for one second! The game isn't perfect but it's great for me. I'll list pros and cons and depending on your taste in games you might have a different experience.

Pros
- Simple to learn system. You move your character to where you want and if they can do an action in that space they will. 
- Character customization: You have your stock plot characters but you can also recruit any of the denizens of the world. You can't change their name or "class" if they're a monster, but you can collect literally 1000 different helmets, (which are somtimes hair styles) weapons, armor etc. Getting a character with a funny name is many a player's goal.
- No bugs for me. I haven't found any bugs yet, or graphical or sound problems.
- I love the music, it wavers between this weird techno to silly haphazard metal.
- The animation is smooth and I like the simple style.

Cons
-The game itself is not complete and that's ok for me, it tells you and you can keep playing after that part in the plot. Technically a con but it's out there in plain site for us to see befor we purchase.
-Atmosphere. I enjoy the abstract and comedic design of the game's world, some people might not. This isn't a dark and brooding tactical rpg clearly. 
- Interface! I DID have trouble figuring out what buttons do what in some cases because they are simpily a graphic, not actually labeled. I don't like how if you hover to another character by accident or another equipment (like from helmets to weapons tab) you go to that field as if you clicked. BUT you can also go there by clicking so it creates some confusion but it's not game breaking or anything. I suggest one interface method or the other when it comes to menu screens. Everywhere else in the game is great.


Watch videos, ask the message boards, check out screenshots, whatever you wanna do. As always see how you feel befor you buy this game and research. I made a good purchase.

29368813.review:
As anyone who is an old fan of The Behemoth, especially 'Castle Crashers', you know what you're getting with 'Pit People'. A deceptively simple turn-based strategy game with all the cartoonish charm and humour of Behemoth's other games. 

Whilst it is by no means flawless in the current state, you can feel a sense of polish and care that gives hope for future development. The game centers around you taking control of a small team of heroes/monsters/mushrooms/cupcakes and taking on other teams of either AI or player controlled enemies in beautiful hex-tile maps. Despite the depth of the damage and weapon types, the healing, debuffing and buffing, counters and weaknesses; your only function as a player is to move your characters. That's it. Whilst that seems uninteresting at first, you quickly find how complex it really is.

You start your game with three characters and must capture individual enemies in order to recruit them to your hero locker-room to be mixed and matched in order to form an ideal team. 

Pros:
- Recognisable and enjoyable art style
- Fantastic soundtrack and SFX
- Simple yet deep combat
- MASSIVE array of cosmetics
- Hilarious writing

Cons:
- Lacking a real vision in what the game wants you to achieve
- Not much character development (Levels seem arbitrary, all gear of the same type have the same stats)
- Will end up being repetitive if turn based strats aren't your genre

My hope for the future is in the developers implementing some kind of (possibly Castle Crashers-esque) character development system. Right now, once you capture a character to use on your team - there is no sense of growth or power. Stat increases from levelling are apparently negligible. As someone who enjoys the 'grind' and progress in my characters, it will eventually be the determining factor on whether I spend 30 hours in the game or 300.

29367045.review:
GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: [u][b]98% YES[/b][/u] / 02% NO

[h1]GOOD[/h1]
[list]
[*]Some of my favorite visuals and animations. An incredibly cute and fun style.
[*]Combat is fun and frantic. You quickly internalize the best way to use the hex-based combat and how the AI targets units. There's a great amount of risk & reward, especially with the units with more powerful ranged attacks.
[*]Daily pit fights are a great way to test your teams out against "unfair AI" as the game lovingly describes them.
[*]An absolute silly amount cosmetic weapons & armor that make constantly refitting your crew a joy.
[*]Overworld is exciting to explore, especially since the space bear moves the town around every so often so you have new maps / areas of the maps to explore.
[*]Side quests galore! So many objectives to complete and even new ones to find in the overworlds. 
[*]You're able to recruit so many units! Around 20 different species to unveil and collect. I've had a blast finding them and trying out their unique abilities. It makes building your 5 spot party intriguing as you wonder if you should have units that only take up 1 spot, 2 spots, poison immune, etc.
[*]The sound effects are incredibly pleasant and spot on. I'll also include the music in this section since it keeps me happy and smiling. They did great work on the soundtrack.
[*]Stamper's back to narrate from his Battleblock Theater debut and he nails it here as the evil space bear.
[*]The developer has stated they're 99% certain there won't be a wipe for data since most of the game is here. The side missions and combat are done, but they're still building the rest of the story missions.
[*]For $15 there's a lot of game in here. It's a great price.
[/list]

[h1]NEUTRAL[/h1]
[list]
[*]The story missions start to drift away from the thrill that is the rest of the game, since I haven't touched the main characters for awhile and they've been out of my parties. Granted the story is still fun, albeit the portion that is being finished. I still love hearing the space bear ring chaos onto the land, but I'm barely invested in Horatio and Pipistrella's quest for revenge. 
[/list]


[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
As an early access title, Pit People nail the fun, frantic nature of turn-based hex combat. Everything's an absolute delight down from the visuals to the soundtrack. I'm eagerly awaiting the full release but that won't stop me from enjoying it a great deal before then.

29366351.review:
Written review below, I also made a video here: [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ridJfjYCiwI&t=6s] Pit People Co-Op Review[/url]

HIghly recommend ths game! Got into the PC Beta and was happy to see that all the progress we had there was moved onwards to the early access. As The Behemoth mentioned, the early access period is only because they realized the game was in a fun playable state. It feels extremely polished from a gameplay standpoint and only really a few gripes I could notice. 

In co-op, if playing with controller, the only to even begin playing is to hit the F2 button which is a little unintuitive, especially if you're away from the keyboard. Further, the camera is shared between players so it's a little hard to navigate through a large map if you end up on both sides. 

Outside of this though, the game is hilariously funny and well made. Really awesome and well made so far with plenty of co-op quests to really have fun with. Nice to have local co-op, haven't tried single player yet but I'm betting it will be super fun as well.

Varias clases con las que componer tu equipo (Humano, Ciclopes, Vampiros, Trolls, Hadas, Unicornios, etc.)
Personalización casi infinita, al igual que los objetos (tanto espadas, como sombreros, escudos o armas arrojadizas. Algunos con efectos especiales/extras).

Podremos centrarnos en diferentes cosas. Ya sea:

-La historia (corta por ahora).
-Misiones secundarias en diferentes 'fases'.
-Misiones que encontraremos por el mapa. 
-Capturar diferentes aliados.
-Arenas (tanto off-line como on-line).

Excelente hasta ahora. PROMETE muchisimo!!

29361938.review: When you hear the name "Pit People", I'm sure the first thing that comes to mind is a game about underground cannibals battling to get to the surface. This game is nothing like that. Yes, I'm pretty sure there's a cannibal or two somewhere. Aside from that, this game has solid, exciting gameplay that never seems to get too boring or repetitive. The humor is so quality that you could impress your dad. Playing co-op is a must. If you don't have a friend, it is worth kidnapping somebody just to experience the multiplayer. I do not think kidnapping is a good idea, but I also think missing out of the multiplayer is like missing out on some of the best fun this game has to offer. Yes, there's still some kinks to iron out, and some things aren't very well explained, leaving you to figure it out on your own. Overall, a very solid of a buy. I'd give it a "rock" rating of solidity.

29361210.review:
[b][u]See written review below[/u][/b] or watch it here: https://youtu.be/RsPh-mTZo8M
[h1]TL;DR: SKIP TO CONCLUSION![/h1]

Pit People is a strategy adventure game with turn-based combat brought to you by the developers who also made BattleBlock Theater and Castle Crashers. Pit People is a different genre of game than their previous games, but the character style and sense of humour is consistent in Pit People as well.

You create a team to with up to 6 characters on it, and battle against the enemies in turn based combat until one team is defeated or your objective is accomplished. I’ve been playing mostly on normal difficulty. I always heal to full health before each encounter, and so far I haven’t found the fights too challenging. I tried a mission on the insane difficulty, and if it wasn’t for my characters leveling up (to restore them to full hp) mid-combat, I would have died for sure. You can bring more than one of the same character type at a time, but the cupcakes don’t heal other cupcakes. If all of your characters die, you lose some gold and maybe some items, but there is no perma-death, so the game is forgiving in that sense.

During your turn you lock in all of your moves at once before ending the turn. If you make a mistake with the move, you can always change it before you end your turn. You are given plenty of time to lock in your moves. The combat has some random factors, like dodging, crits, and most notably which target you actually hit. You have control over your team’s movement, but you have no say as to which target you will actually attack. For example: if you place a character in a hex that’s adjacent to multiple targets, your character can attack any of the available targets, and not necessarily the target you want. There is friendly fire with AE abilities, and you can accidentally heal enemies as well. 

You journey out from town to explore, or complete missions by driving around the map in a nitro-boosted wagon...that poops. There are enemies everywhere, but it’s nice that you can easily avoid combat by stunning them and running past if you want to. It’s a lot better than having to flee combat, since fleeing makes all of your characters take damage, and drops your items on the ground. 

You can play by yourself against the AI, or in two player co-op either online or locally. There is voice and text chat In co-op, so you can coordinate easier. Both you and your ally take your turns at the same time, and there are a lot more enemies to compensate for there being a second player. There is also an arena where you can battle against other players in 2v2 battles or compete for scores on the leaderboard against AI.

In almost every battle, you have the option to recruit the last remaining enemy by capturing them with a net and cage. I think it’s awesome that you can capture any enemy you come across, and that it never fails to capture. It’s also neat that you get to keep all of the equipment that they are wearing when you are recruit them. Sometimes I wish I could capture more than one enemy per battle though. There are different species that have special abilities, and other species that can be equipped with gear. There are no skill points to allocate, but the equipment let’s you customize each character.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list][*]the same Behemoth style and humour
[*]lots of side quests to do, and some have their own mini stories to go with them
[*]TONS of collectible items to find - most are purely cosmetic, while others have various combat stats, and you can also trade items with other players (I played for about 10 hours, and only got 9% complete)
[*]the gameplay is fun, but can get repetitive after a while (I still got my money's worth)
[*]voice acting for the narrative (Will Stamper, from BattleBlock Theater) is amazing, and the goofy made-up language with voice acting is rather entertaining at times
[*]most of the sound effects are decent, and soundtrack is good, but it won’t appeal to everyone.
[*]good looking unique and colourful environments that are all designed with hexes
[*]awesome animations, and fantastic character customizations
[*]keybindings are fully customizable, and there is full controller support[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list][*]the game lacks a full-sized map that shows all the areas you’ve explored - since you can only have 2 active quests at a time, it would be nice to have a large map marking points of interest you’ve seen, but not yet completed
[*]not much of the main story it available yet as expected in early access (but at least there are a lot of side quests available)
[*](nitpick) the clouds everywhere blocking vision while driving around is annoying
[*](nitpick) the randomness of which targets you actually hit can be a pain sometimes
[*](nitpick) it can sometimes be hard to tell which hexes you can’t walk on
[*](nitpick) when you are running through enemies avoiding combat the aggro sound is quite irritating (they should lower the radius that prompts the sound)[/list]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
If you’re hoping for story, there isn’t much in the way of a story campaign just yet, but there are still plenty of quests to do.  Playing against the AI as single player is fun, but it feels repetitive after a while. The co-op is enjoyable, but I wasn’t able to try the PvP since I got impatient waiting for it to pop. Overall, it’s a nicely polished turn-based strategy game that’s not too punishing, and it has an abundance of collectibles, and the sense of humour you would expect from a Behemoth title. I have no regrets with the purchase, and I look forward to more of the story being added.

If you like my reviews, please feel free to join my Steam group, and follow my curations [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AzralynnReviews#curation]here.[/url]
You can also view this review on my website [url=http://www.azralynn.com/review-pit-people-game-early-access/]here.[/url]

29350257.review:
First of all, i have never heard of the behemoth. But, i have played games at newgrounds a long time ago and it was fun. I was looking at some indie rogue like games and suddenly i saw castle crashers a few weeks ago. Then, i saw that pit people will be releasing on 13th January. 

After watching a few gameplay videos, I bought the game on that day and knowing that it is release as early access. i have played turn based strategy like ff tactics and tactics ogre. This game definately attract my interest. For me, i really like the humor that resembles rick and morty. The animation that resembles adventure time and catchy soundtrack. The gameplay is quite simple and the difficulty level is okay. They also provide insane difficulty level. Loots are basically reskin of equipable item and only few provide different attributes such as elemental resistance or damage. It is understandable due to there are too many items. Maybe different stats for items will be implement by dev or not. I am okay with that.

The game is still at early access stage. Some people are complainig about the short main story. But it is not a problem for me. Within 11 hours of playing this game, i did not touch the main story. I only played side quest, explore the map, catching units and played pvp. PVP is quite interesting because of the leaderboard motivates me to get a better position on it. It is understandable that finding people on online match is quite hard for sea server. But it is easy to find people in online coop for me.

This is my opinion. I recommend this to people who like this kind of game. You could watch youtube for gameplay. If you only want to play single player, it is advised to wait for the full game to be released.

[h1]Encore une réussite pour The Behemot ![/h1]

Ayant joué à l'excellent [i]Castle Crashers[/i] et au délirant [i]Battleblock Theater[/i], c'est sans hésitation que je me suis pris [b]Pit People[/b]. Et j'adore ! On retrouve la patte graphique et l'humour décalé de Behemot pour notre plus grand plaisir.
Pit People est un RPG tactique au gameplay simple et efficace. On compose son équipe en "recrutant" (disons plutôt en capturant) des adversaires lors des combats. On peut les customiser de manière purement esthétique et les armer avec de nombreux items : il y en a plus de 1300 actuellement !

On suit l'histoire d'un paysan dont le fils a été kidnappé par un ours de l'espace (oui oui, vous avez bien entendu), et d'une princesse dont le père a été tué par de vilains bandits. Ceci compose la trame principale du jeu, incomplète à l'heure actuelle puisque le jeu est en accès anticipé. Pit People nous propose de nombreuses quêtes secondaires toutes aussi délirantes les unes que les autres.

La mappemonde du jeu est déterminée aléatoirement parmi 3 cartes actuellement par l'ours de l'espace. Elle est composée d'une capitale et de nombreux lieux de quêtes. 
La capitale dispose de nombreuses fonctionnalités :
[list]
    [*]Un magasin
    [*]Une arène pour des combats contre l'IA ou en 2v2 contre des joueurs en ligne ou en local !
    [*]Une maison pour personnaliser son équipe
    [*]Et je vous laisse découvrir le reste
[/list]

Le jeu est donc [b]jouable en solo ou en coopération locale ou en ligne[/b]. C'est ce qui en fait la force !

Le prix du jeu sera un peu plus élevé à sa sortie, donc n'hésitez pas à vous procurer Pit People !

29342955.review:
Hi friends, 

This is the only game thats inspiried me to actually write a review.  If you enjoy games like Final Fantasy Tatics you'll love this game.  Although this is still early access the game is very much complete although some of the story is missing.  Not only is it hilarious but the game is very fullfilling to play.  

The reason I've already played 24+ hours of this game is because of the pit.  The Pit is a place you can use the characters you've developed to fight other people in 1v1 or 2v2.  There are countless classes, weapons, armor and tatics on how you can win your next battle.

After each battle if you keep 1 person alive you can capture him/her/it and it will join your team.  Any battle you encounter you can capture 1 of the enemies no matter how large they may be.  You then can use its armor/weapons to put on your other characters or keep them whole.  

I'd easily pay $50 for the game as it is right now.  One of the best games i've played in a long time.  If your on the fence, buy it, you won't regret it.

Much love and life!

29332187.review:
[b][h1][u]Fast-paced Turn-based Fun Place![/u][/h1][/b]
What's this? The Behemoth, the creators of my favorite beat-em-up and one of my favorite platformers, made a turn-based game? Sign me up!

I'm a fan of turn-based games with RPG elements: the Fallout games by Interplay, Wasteland, Fire Emblem, the works. Seeing this game annouced, I was a little skeptical. Specifically, about the co-op features. Many turn-based games with co-op have each player move individually. But I'll be beaten down with a rubber hose filled with frozen custard if The Behemoth didn't make it work.

I can easily compare the gameplay to Fire Emblem, but boiled down to what's important. No faffing about with the weapon triangle for Pit People! Bigger weapons do more damage but weigh more. Archers aren't effective at close range. Maces work better on armored foes. Ultimately, the secret to success is how you position your soldiers on the field. Different squads can mesh together in different ways, allowing for interesting stratigies that work for you.

The humor is nothing new if you've played Behemoth's previous, with the glorious glorious voice of Stamper, the narrator in Battleblock Theatre, making a return as the narrator. This time around he's made out to be super sarcastic and passive-aggressive towards the protagonists. It's truly a joy to behold the dialouge. But as they say, the devil's in the details. Pit People has a lot of tiny details that make it much more enjoyable. For example, each unit type has a special entry corralating to them. And the entries are just an absolute joy.

This game is a-okay in my book!

I don't know much about Pit People, but I do know the plot for JoJo's Bizarre Adventure!
In 1999 in the town of Morioh located in S-City, Josuke Higashikata is a popular boy in high school who becomes quick friends with one of his classmates, Koichi Hirose. When Josuke's nephew Jotaro Kujo (who's older than he is due to his father being his nephew's grandfather, hence the age difference) appears, Josuke is suddenly pulled into the world of the supernatural powers known as stands. One of DIO's henchmen has brought the Bow and Arrow to Morioh and someone has been using it on various people in the town creating Stand users—as discovered when one of them, the murderer Anjuro "Angelo" Katagiri, uses the power of his Stand Aqua Necklace to try and kill Josuke for interfering with his plans to rob a store and generally disturb the peace in Morioh earlier. Aqua Necklace manages to kill Josuke's grandfather, Ryohei Higashikata, in revenge for him being jailed by him. Josuke and Jotaro eventually capture him and, as a consequence of insulting Josuke's hair, ends up getting fused to the rock he was leaning on at the time, becoming a tourist attraction known as "Angelo Rock" in the process.

29324686.review:
Pit People est un jeu que j'attendais depuis longtemps : déjà fidèle à The Behemoth, quand j'ai vu les trailers je me suis dit que c'était un jeu pour moi, fan de tactical RPG.

Ce jeu est pour moi un Fire Emblem sauce The Behemoth et c'est parfait, car j'adhère totalement ! Il y a tout ce qu'il manque à la série FE selon moi (bien que n'ayant pas joué aux plus récents à savoir à partir de FE:Awakening) : une map à naviguer librement, des objets cosmétiques à collectionner, des succès ...

Pit People est très original pour les classes de personnage qu'il propose : il offre un gameplay intéressant et très varié, chacun joue à sa manière avec sa team, qu'on peut custom de milles et une façon. J'ai un coup de coeur pour les pixies qui sont trop mimi et puissantes, mais aussi les mascottes qui servent à booster votre équipe, et qui en cas de coup dur peuvent servir de kamikazes !

Quelques bémols cependant :
- musiques pas top top, je trouve que celles de Battleblock Theater et Castle Crashers sont bien plus accrochantes, entraînantes (bien que je n'ai pas encore tous les vinyles) : surtout celles des combats qui doivent former une boucle et dont on ne se lasse pas ! D'ailleurs la musique de map-monde n'est pas une boucle, c'est dommage.
- On ne remarque pas la progression des personnages à travers le leveling. Un perso plus haut lvl doit normalement faire plus de dégâts et avoir plus de vie mais on ne le sent pas trop. Peut-être que c'est voulu car il y a un mode PvP et il faudrait soit faire des paliers pour équilibrer, soit il faudrait faire comme la tour de combat dans Pokémon (bloquer à un lvl et baisser le niveau des persos au dessus de la limite)
- JE VEUX LA SUITE DE L'HISTOIRE :@ bon le jeu est en early-access, c'est normal

29324486.review:
Note: While this game IS early access right now, the only thing you can't do right now is the complete story. Everything else works very well and is the most feature complete game I've seen in early access. 

Having played a number of turn-based tactics game I really like this game. This game moves quickly by giving the player only one important choice of where to move their units. Each unit then moves to a point and performs their ability/attack. Games like Final Fantasy Tactics or Fire Emblem can take 30-60 minutes to complete a single mission while you can finish a battle in Pit People in like 10-20 minutes.

Each character in the game has a race and equipment that you can customize. You can even recruit new party members by capturing them in battle. This offers huge replay value and the ability to create all sorts of combinations. I love how there is plenty of cosmetic variations as well.

This is Behemoth's best game. A great game with high replay value. The best part is this completely a co-op game in all features. You can play the story mode together, fight each other, or take on the world together.

29324344.review:
So, keep in mind this is an early acces review!

I waited for this game oh so long! When I first saw the trailers, I knew it would fit my sense of humour. When it hit early access recently I was not disappointed.
You want to whack your enemies with an oversized lollipop or a nuke, misused as a club? Check!
You want to have the weirdest outfits for your heroes that you can imagine? Check! (And I am not exagerating.)
You want absolutely hillarious characters and missions? Check!

The only disadvantage from owning this gem in early access: The story line is not finished. After one Story mission the progress (for the story) stops. However, you have a shit load of side bonus quests and some side missions to do. And of course you have the map to explore and try to "hire" all the different types of enemies (meaning: You put them in a cage and drag them back home).
Combat system is easy enough, but leaves enough unpredictability (especially since a lot of your weapons will damage whoever is unlucky enough to be in their radius, no matter if friend or foe) to make it a real trial in every fight.
I love it and cannot wait for the game to be finished.

The pit est un jeu stratégie au tour par tour avec la magie des dév' de the Behemoth ; histoire barrée, humour, et bonne mécanique. A cela je rajoute une ost du diable comme d'habitude ! Sans rapport, dommage qu'elle en soit pas dispo à l'achat ! Sinon c'était "shut ut and take my money".

Ayant déjà littéralement poncé castle crashers sur xbox 360 puis ensuite steam, puis ensuite un peu battleblock theater (moins certe mais j'attend mon ami pour jouer ^^'). A chaque fois un concept nouveau, mais en gardant cette patte graphique "the behemoth".

Je vais plus y jouer dans les jours prochains mais dès la première seconde, le decor est planté, je le surkiff dejà. De nouvelles idées tip top ! Le groupe peut être augmenté, un nouveau personnage sert en gros de "captureur" d'ennemi pour en faire un allier pour la suite. Le truc ENORME (en plus grosse majuscule je devrais dire) c'est que nous pouvons capturer chaque ennemis du monde ! C'est un peu le même principe que castle crashers ou nous pouvions jouer chaque personnage (même les plus pourrave visuellement). Une rejouabilitée de dingue en gros. De plus, un petit rien stratégique par exemple, le healer tape dans ses points de vie pour vous heal ... va falloir bien réfléchir car c'est une cible qui ne se bat pas et qui souvent prend dans la bouche !

J'ai hate d'avancer plus, de découvrir les nouveaux perso, les nouvelles capa et c'est un très bon point pour un jeu early accès ; j'ai une grosse envi d'y revenir !

Je mettrai une belle maj sur cette évaluation dès que j'ai poncé ce jeu.

Et une petite vidéo du début pour ce faire une idée =)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B7lNp4BokxQ&t=409s

29315814.review:
The various job clases of Fire Emblem meet XCOM's crazy RNG and then for the cherry on top, add a whole bunch of crude humor, references, and memes with the art style and explosions The Behemoth loves to show off. Throw in RNG for which character will get attacked by a unit, what hex tiles Area of Effect will splash into, if a unit blocks a projectile, and/or a unit dodging melee attacks and you have a wacky, chaotic, and hilarious game. Co-op is a lovely touch that will have you raging or laughing with a buddy over kill stealing or friendly fire incidents that just comes down to RNG.

Rainbow Horses having the runs and skid marking the battlefield as they scoot across tiles is such a subtle and brilliant touch.

12 Kobold rushers in PvP are goofy. As are teams of Zombies and Rainbow Horses. PvP will be getting balance patches and the unit combinations and customizations will slowly form a "build of the week" until a meta is formed.

29314864.review:
Pit People is off to a good start, with a few issues that will hopefully be worked on in the future. A warning: the Story content is limited at the moment, with most of the gameplay coming from building your team, working out strong team compositions and side questing/exploring. There's a good few hours of gameplay here and battling in the pit is very addictive.

The game works great on a keyboard and mouse, but there's a confusing mix of KB/M specific interface icons and Controller Icons currently. In some cases it's unclear which button I need to be pressing. Additionally, combat can also feel clunky when it comes to selecting the correct character and it would be nice if the game could be played without needing to use the keyboard - a clickable end turn button etc would probably do the trick.

The game's also rather obtuse in a number of areas. There doesn't appear to be an in-game explanation of a number of the attribute icons as yet. Many are obvious (breaks helmets, inflicts fire damage, blocks ranged attacks) yet some aren't clear at all. The equip menu itself is also pretty clunky and unintuitive initially.

Worth checking out now if you're a fan of the Behemoth, otherwise perhaps wait a little while.

29313464.review:
[h1]Le nouveau joyau du studio déjanté The Behemoth[/h1]

Pit People est un tour par tour RPG dans lequel vous allez jouer un paysan, qui, après s’être fait  enlever son enfant, va partir à l'aventure accompagné d'une princesse dont le père a été tué par des bandits.  
Vous créerez un groupe de combattant en les capturant ou en réalisant des quêtes. 
Vous les équiperez avec une vaste panoplie d'arme et de skin, le tout sur une carte grande et variée.

[b]Il y a possibilité de jouer en mode histoire (solo/local/online) et en arène contre IA ou joueurs (solo/local/online).[/b]

[u]Après quelques heures, voila mon sentiment pour les +[/u]
-L'univers fun, varié et beau de The behemot 
-La musique
-L'histoire et l’arène en Coop Local/online
-Le tableau de Rank pour l’arène 
-Les variations de la carte 
-Un dépoussiérage du tour par tour
-Attrapez les tous!
-Les conseils de la girafe 

[u]Mon sentiment pour les -[/u]
-Les armes ne sont pas bien balancées 
-Le niveau de difficulté est simple ou trop dur
-La progression est invisible
-Le zoom intempestif en combat

Aprés Castle Crasher, Alien Hominid, et BattleBlock Theather, The Behemoth réussi le parie audacieux du genre, et nous offre un bon jeux de stratégie entre pokemon et XCOM, mais avec la coop et le fun en plus.

Pour illustrer:  https://youtu.be/L0QTR8ygnLE

Il n'y a rien à dire à part, [h1]FONCEZ![/h1]

29311657.review:
This is an amazing game right now, but there are some major areas that could use improvment.
This review will only be listing the flaws, but rest assured, it earns that positive rating.

-No Zoom in or out
This is vital to nearly all SRPGS, being able to zoom out to see most, if not all of the battle field at all times. This allows for the best and most tactical disicions possible, and give the player all the info they need without hassle.
In this game, your constantly looking through bonoculars magnetically taped to your forehead by Stamper with no way of taking them off because of that metal plate you goit in your head.
Seriosuly, why did you think that was a good idea?

-Not many Varried objectives
Most maps boil down to "Kill the enemy". While this is a fine, morally Upstanding goal, it can get a tad boring at times. The few defend and seiges maps work greatat showing the strengths and weaknesses of each race, class, unit, and otherwise.
However, when the Maps are almost entirly "Kill these guys", it makes some units undeniably better then others, such as Fredrick.
Speaking of which...

-Fredrick is too Powerful
I though I was done with him when I was finshed with Awakening for the 7th time.
I though I had found a game without a ludicrusly Overpowered unit.
I was wrong.
Fredrick the Cyclops, with his long flowing Magenta hair, Tiny turtle shell sheild, and Nucular Bomb Club, was far too powerful for the rest of my units too keep up. Even taking up two slots wasn't enough to stop this deminsiopn hopping monstrosity. His two move seemd like a reasonable nerf.
HA.
That was only so the enemies could pickl a god and pray one last time before their inevitable demise.
The only map he ever struggled with was the Lumberjack one, and that's 'cuse he hate's lumberjacks and long distances.
Nothing could stand up to him, not even other cyclopses.
When the undead came crawling, he put them back in the grave. He wasn't afraid to kil. Again and again.
It didn't matter that he took damage from his bomb.
It didn't even mater that we lacked a healer for most of the game.
Fredrick could not be killed.
Fredrick could not be stopped.
Fredrick was a force of nature.

And it wasn't enough he was that strong, he was ALWAYS the one talking too. He was the leader of this rag tag group he called a team. Sure, his ego was about as through the roof as his strength, but he had twice as much bite for every bark you'd even THINK he had.

But, as amazing as he is, all good things must end. Fredrick is too overpowered. I'd be happy to see him nerfed, in exchange for seeing him more in the story, with his FLowing purple, deep, muscly voice and suprisingly sensable values.

-The terrain sometimes black the veiw of the units
Despite how massive Fredick is even compared to other cyclopses, there were times where the terrain even obscured HIM. Just making the terrain a unit is standing behind less opaque would solve this issue immediately.

-The healers don't heal enough
'nuff said. You need two to make them even think about being useful, and even then, that's a slot that could be used to bring ANOTHER cyclops to use with Fredrick.

-More unique weapons
I want more weapons that DO things.
I love re-skins as much as the next guy, but it can make it hard to tell what some enemies are capable of, and that can SUCK. Besides, it would make getting a new weapon exciting rathen then "Oh, what's this reskin?"

-Sopfia Sucks
I understand that the "Capture" unit shouldn't be a godess. But COME ON, she is SO WEAK compared to everyone else. If she had visable utility outside of capturing, like maybe some abilities to help with defend of seige maps, that might make her useful. But, since every map is "Kil, Kill, KILL" she's an active detriment. 
Besides, once you capture Fredrick, there is no need to capture anyone else, so she becomes useless.

-Status effects Suck
Theres no point to avaoiding them because they suck so much.

-More unique characters
I like how Gluten got his own side quest. I want more units like him, who get some soft of quest to go along with them.
I would say restrict the quests so you HAVE to have them in your party, though. For story reasons.

-Show more of the other main characters in the story
Horatio and Pimpstella are suprisingly engaging characters, but I felt myself wondering during some of these scenes "Where's Yslove? Where's Sofia? Where's Glutan? Where's Fredrick?"
These are all characters introduced in the main story, but never get any appearences in the main story, and rarely appear in sidequests (Aside from Yslove). Even if they are not present, they should have at least a little more of an impact.


-PVP's kinda crap
When your losing, there's not many ways to "Win". Though, this is more of an SRPG problem then just this game, so that's why it's last.

-Tell us what our team is strong and weak aginst when we build it
This is more of a request, but I want to see what our team is most effective against and what their weakest to, both Map-wise and Enemy wise. I want to see the game itself acknowledge Fredrick is overpowered. Those purple locks just make him too good.

All in all, great game, but I clearly see why it's in early acess.
I understand Fredrick must be nerfed, But I'd prefer it done in more clever ways, and to see him intereact more with the story.
Good luck on your game development, Gentlemen, And I shall be off!
Fredrick, Pull our cart away!

29309172.review:
After playing it for a while, dropping it, and then going back to play it again, allow me to provide an updated review.
For the record, I do know its an early access game. Ok.

Take the art style and humor of Castle Crashers with 100% less poop jokes thank the heavens. Weave said elements into Fire Emblem; and you have Pit People. 

The game wastes no time thrusting you into the plot; which is fairly straightforward, and cliched in nature but hey. You're not actually here for the plot, lets be alarmingly real with ourselves.

You're here for the sense of humor, and it delievers. 
The gameplay is b a s i c a l l y older Fire Emblem. Grid based chess with everyone usually having a weakness; but unlike FE; they don't throw a bunch of numbers and stats at you (To take words from Konjin; attacks don't really enter double digits much so when you get slapped down the map for 15, it has a legit impact, so yeah you're not hit with tons of numbers) and more importantly; planning isn't really needed.
You don't know how much damage any shot is gonna do, nor if it'll even hit (if you're running an archer or similar for example)
You don't know how far each dude can move.
You don't really know what the items dude have can do until you get hit by it and see you're poisoned suddenly.
You don't even know how many life points you have. You just kinda exist in a limbo of not being too sure.

The AI isn't great here. If you're running a pegasus knigh in FE; you main focus is gonna be where the archers are; and all that, ranges, and the best way to stab them. Here; you don't know how far dudes can move, you can see the archers but as for their range; you really don't know. You can only guess. And even if you guess wrong there is no risk. Here, Vampiress' are damaged more by arrows but they don't get targeted?
At least it doesn't seem like they do? Maybe I'm wrong. I likely am. 

Nonetheless; in FE if you threw a flying horse anywhere close to the range of an archer; the thing will get shot right out of the sky. 
the AI I guess doesn't want to target weaknesses; and it barely targets more hurt dudes. Heck, fellows with swords will go after helmeted protags despite the fact that they're at a disadvantage whilst doing so.

I think the thing I dislike the most about this entire game is the fact that the fighters you control will choose who to fight.
Yes. That not-good AI basically rolls a dice and smacks around how it wishes. This was done, I know, so that the squids will have an actual purpose, but that gimmick is only ever ok. Its hilarious to see it work, but its only ok. The AI needs fixed for this effect to mean anything more really, and its only useful against the AI, since all you need to do is force the afflicted dude away. So; I have two ideas: remove squids, and let us have full control over our fighters. Let us decide who dies. 


Another bothersome flaw with this here game is relocating the city. Why, exactly? So that you don't get used to the map? To present the illusion of having a limited amount of time to captures dudes to your cause? I haven't the foggiest. (inspired by another review)


Each mission is super FE. Its all the same and thats only a bad thing if you see it that way. Let me channel my innter Yahtzee: You effectively go to the place and stab the lads.
Lets be clear. 3/4ths of the game is exactly that.
Each quest provides a funny reason as to why you went to the place and stab the lads, but in the end, you're still just going to the place to stab the lads.
You can save one lad to live to be captured to your side if you have a cage and you will because they're cheap.
This mechanic is awesome and I really enjoy it.
The lads that you can play as, are a varied as they come. From Gorons, to vampiress, to your run of the mill swordsmen and archers, to cyclops with big ol mallets, to wraths (a personal favorite) that offer debuffs at a range; to cupcakes that fling themselves to heal others.

The cosmetics they have are staggering an amusing in their own right, the weapons you get are in their own classes and are wildly creative and also funny, and each dude you kill has a random name. 
Generally you choose weapons based off of what they look like. No joke. Execpt that i s a joke.
I can say whatever I want about anything, right?

But time, effort, and love was pouring into each line of code of this game. 
Some of the items and cosmetics are named after the long gone memes of yesteryear but irony is alive and well.
I will wear the hat that looks like a Shiba Inu, which flashes the word 'wow' around itself and dang nabbit I will stab the lads.

early access/10

29308448.review:
Pit People is XCOM, Fire Emblem, and Pokemon thrown into the minds of Behemoth and what they made is a funny and good looking game. The meat of the game is doing battle with teams of bad guys with your very own squad that you find through the story mode until you find Sophia the Recruitador (a lot of characters in this game have funny names). Then, the game branches into another way of playing it. You can capture any unit you fight on the battlefield when you leave it as the last one alive. There are several character classes from the human fighters to the penguins to the beefy giants to the cupcake healer class. Every character has their own name from Gluten to Pipistrella.

This is an early access title as of January, and it shows only in the story mode. The rest of the game is polished and balanced with each weapon type and class, but the story mode is farly short. What it lacks in length it makes up in character and gameplay. The narrator Stamper was present in their previous game Battleblock Theater as well but he takes the role of a godlike bear that overlooks the story as a sort of meta-narrator, talking to the characters and talking to the player. Apart from the short story quests, there are a few side quests that are all five parts incrasing in difficulty. These serve the same purpose as side quests in different games, to give you some more gold and flesh out the characters. These side quests take a bit longer than the story. 

Apart from the insanely fun singleplayer, there exists an in-universe multiplayer PvP called the Pit, which is pretty much the only reference to the title of the game. You and a partner control your squads to defeat two other people's squads. It's a very satisfying game mode as you can learn from the other people's squad composition to increase chances of success. Think XCOM PvP. You get story rewards as well depending on how many games you win per day. As it is now, Pit People is very fun and well balanced even though the story mode was short and as sweet as the cupcake healer class.

29303119.review:
Bon, je dois bien reconnaître que je suis un peu déçu, et je regrette terriblement que ce soit le cas. 
J'adore la pâte graphique et le style général de The Behemoth, mais Pit People ne passe juste pas, et ce à cause d'un gros point négatif : le côté stratégie du jeu est très, très simple. Trop simple. Au point que cet aspect va purement et simplement s'avérer ennuyant. Jetez vos personnages dans la mélée, et spammez espace jusqu'à ce vous ayez gagné, et vous passerez sans encombre l'ensemble des niveaux. 

Le jeu propose cependant un aspect "Pleins de trucs à récolter" plutôt sympa, mais l'absence de différence en dehors de l'apparence de la plupart des armes est plutôt decevante. Chaque item appartient à une "catégorie" (Arme légère, lourde, moyenne, massue) et chacune de ces catégories aura des stats d'attaque bien précises, cependant les armes au sein d'une même catégorie ne seront pas différentes en terme de stats. Certaines apporteront de petits bonus (Saignements, repousse, dégats élémentaires) mais rien de suffisant pour encourager la récolte d'arme.
De la même façon, vous pourrez recruter de nombreux types de personnages différents disposants chacuns de capacités propres, cependant vous en faites vite le tour et le manque d'information par rapport à certaines unités peut s'avérer handicapant. (Impossible de savoir la portée d'une unité à longue distance)

Sur une note plus positive, c'est du Behemoth. Les musiques sont sympas, le style graphique est absolument génial et l'humour est présent. L'humour est cependant plus cynique qu'absurde, notamment si on le compare avec celui de Battleblock Theater. Donc oui c'est toujours un peu absurde, mais moins. 

Malgré cela, l'ennui ressenti lors des phases de stratégie m'empêche purement et simplement de profiter de ce jeu. 
Je ne recommanderais donc pas Pit People à l'heure actuelle, à cause de son manque de profondeur au niveau du gameplay. Si vous aimez les jeux de stratégie sans prise de tête et plutôt simples, pourquoi pas. Si vous êtes fan de The Behemoth, à essayer.


Je tiens également à préciser que cet avis tient compte du jeu lorsque celui ci est devenu disponible, quand aucune màj n'était dispo. Donc peut-être que certains points sont à présent corrigés.

Will Stamper, there's Will Stamper. They got the legendary comedian Will Stamper. Just like Battleblock Theater, I might have a reason to beat the game.
Unlike any Early Acess Games, I couldn't find any bugs when just casually playing it. It's well constructed, and like I said earlier, It feels like this is the full game.
If you, the reader, are reading this, I highly recommend you buy this.  If you can spare $15, just buy this, buy this for your family, and buy it for your dog.

다만 스토리를 클리어하더라도, 월드를 돌아다니며 서브퀘스트를 할 수 있고, Pit라는 투기장비슷한 곳에서 멀티플레이어로 다른 플레이어와 전투가 가능합니다.
아 그리고 턴제라서 그런지 로컬 코옵도 가능합니다.
베히모스 게임답게 심플하지만 고어한 표현의 그래픽과 좋은 OST는 게임할때 재미를 더하는것 같습니다.

According to Steam I dumped 18 hours into the Closed Beta during the week+ it was going on. I haven't replayed the main quest yet to see the finished animations and whatnot, but just from the short amount of time I've run around the map in the Early Access version, I'm seeing the same fun game but with [i]more[/i]. More quests, more loot, more customization, more ridiculously good time.

Whereas the quirks of the Narrator and the occasional plotpoint rearing its head has put Battleblock Theater at the top of the list, for Pit People it is the sheer massiveness of the content combined with the replay value. I foresee this game being a favourite of a lot of people for the coming years, myself included. There's just so much to do and discover, and no chance of it tapping out any time soon.

Highly recc getting this game, even in Early Access. It's a complete game, you just have to wait for the rest of the main quest to unlock. That's not so bad, right? In the meantime, there's a multi-tiered quest in Tinkletown waiting for your assistance.

29293532.review:
Простая и веселая пошаговая игра. Всё в духе предыдущих творений от Begemoth, а значит фирменный юмор, отличнейшая рисовка, возможность весело играть в с друзьями на одном компе/консоли, и главное офигеннейшая озвучка присутствуют.

Сами пошаговые бои выглядят достаточно просто - никаких шансов попадания и кучи скучных всплывающих характеристик, все что нам нужно знать, мы видим сразу на герое - это сам герой и его экипировка, вариаций которой тысячи :) 

Отдаем приказы перемещения всем героям нажимаем PLAY - и понеслась, каждый герой бежит в указанную точку и атакует ближайшего врага (да, да, нам даже не дают выбирать кого атаковать). Причем все это происходит одновременно для всех героев, что выглядит немного сумбурно и забавно, когда на поле в разных местах летят искры, брызжет кровь и отлетают цифры критов :)
Затем то же самое делает противник. И так до победы :) После боя получаем "ништяки": золото, новые виды экипировки (например, меч в виде планки оперативной памяти(!), или метательные лампочки) и конечно же "экспу"

На первый взгляд все выглядит просто, но разнообразие тактик достигается разнообразием героев и их умений. Самих героев можно вербовать, а можно брать в плен из врагов путешествуя по глобальной карте. Здесь же выполняем сюжетные квесты, достаточно забавные и юморные. Например спасти кексик, который хотят съесть на свадьбе, и да, кексик здесь - это герой, хилер, который лечит своим кремом наших героев :)
Путешествуем по глобальной карте в риалтайме - и здесь можно отбиваться от врагов стреляя по ним мортирой, установленной в вашем вагончике, таким образом избегая сильных врагов... 

Вердикт: БРАТЬ, ибо играть весело и ненапряжно, что редкость для ПОШАГОВЫХ стратегий/тактик

29292664.review:
Pit people is a game made by Behemoth, and that's why it's good!


That's it, go home.




























You're still here?



Aaagh, fine.


I'll keep things simple by explaining all things this game could be compared to.



Because I'm lazy.


Adventure Time: definitely. The game is set in a colorful, cartoonish fantasy world that has some elements of the modern world (and also takes place after the apocalypse). The main character is just a normal guy who suddenly becomes a hero and meets all kinds of crazy characters, fights monsters and hangs out with 3 friends: a princess, a sexy Spanish lady and his cyclops bro. The game also mixes random humor and serious moments like the show.

XCOM: Eeeeeeh. Apparently every turn based RPG game is going to be compared to XCOM 2012 these days. I'm just going to say that this is bullshit. There's no permadeath or saving the world from the alien invasion (not yet at least) but you can create your 6 member team from randomly generated characters, but honestly I would rather compare this game to Final Fantasy Tactics series and other games from the Turn Based Strategy RPG gentre.

Pokemon: now that may sound weird, but let me explain. You can recruit all sorts of characters and creatures with different abilities to your team, but it works in a different way than you would expect. When you're fighting someone and see a character you want in your team, you need to leave that unit alone and kill everyone else, then you can make someone drop a cage on this unit and BAM: now it's yours. There's a ton of different units you can find, and also all of them have strenghts and weaknesses against others.

Other Behemoth games: IMO it might be the best game they ever made. The gameplay is super cool, the humor is fantastic and the artstyle is really good as well.



Now you might think two different things depending of what kind of person you are.


1. "Ham Man, I don't play turn based RPG's that much/I never played a turn based RPG in my life, will I enjoy this?"

It's not as complicated as for example Final Fantasy Tactics on PS1, the rules are pretty simple and you should learn how to play quickly.

2."Ham Man, I played turn based RPG's all my life, will this game challenge my genius mind and allow me to destroy powerful enemies with flawless tactics?"

I know that I said that the game is simple literally 30 seconds ago, but don't be alarmed. The game can offer a fair amount of challenge as well. There's Insane Mode that greatly increases the difficulty, Unfair Challenge that makes you fight 3 battles in one go (yes, there is Insane Unfair Challenge), you can also fight other players. There's a ton of different ways you can build your team and some characters have good synergy with others. Tactical planning and using the abilities of your heroes well is important in PVP and harder challenges.




Well, I think that's it.


The game is cool, buy it.



Bye.

29292264.review:
Like all Behemoth's games, Pit People is very polished and it brings something interesting (and funny) to the table. If you have played Castle Crashers or BattleBlock Theater, there are a lot of familiar things you will encounter - art style, humor and the narrator to mention a few.

Pit People does not necessarily innovate something new. Rather, it combines mechanics from many popular games and ends up creating quite an interesting result. You will feel the presence of XCOM, Fire Emblem, Skulls of the Shogun or damn, even Pokemon. Most of the time games mixing that many ideas would end up being bad. This is not the case with Pit People - it feels truly original.

The combat is plain simple but vast collection of different unit types and items make this game quite strategical. There are endless amount of combos to test and new interesting characters to find.

Lastly, I wouldn't be too worried about the Early Access tag on this game. Sure, most of the main story is missing (you can only complete about 5% of it) but there is still a lot to do in this version. There are multiple plot driven side quests to do, units to catch and other players to crush (in online mode). 

Highly recommend.

29291261.review:
For a game that's early access, it really doesn't feel like it. I'm going to highlight what I feel is wrong/needs to be improved, in hopes the devs see it and consider it. For a review, I'll keep  it short. A very interesting world, full of LOTS of stuff, like LOTS, complete with music, great sound, and mostly good controls The music is amazing, I'll have it stuck in my head for days. Behemoth has yet another wonderful game out on the market. On to some gripes about the game.

The PC controls are mostly good, but could use some fine tuning to make them not so wonky when selecting loadouts, the default controls are questionable, but rebindable so that's not that big of a deal. Also, in the intro, the load out screen and differences between "tiers" of items (i.e. cosmetics, light helmets, heavy helmets) isn't at all explained. It was super super confusing because I had no clue what I was doing. So the tutorial could use some more fine tuning as well. 

There are other things not very well explained, like what's on the HUD, I didn't know what I was looking at, or what it meant for a while. The items, such as campfires, and how to buy them isn't at all explained. I think my #1 glaring problem was the lack of explanation, so if you're reading this, Behemoth, it would be good to look into that.

These are the most notable issues I saw, but damn this game is freaking fun. Doing Coop is sooooo much fun, but online is a mess. The biggest thing this game could benefit from is more flushed out tutorials, really explaining what everythng is. Keep it up Behemoth, it's a damn good game. Also, put people queued together on the same team. Or at least have an option to.

29290995.review:
I'm excited to see the limited amount of content grow. 
Behemoth has always done a great job putting together unique games with their own sense of humor and style. As of early access, they still deliever with their signature style. 
The art of Dan Paladin is ever present. Simple, humorous, delightful. There were a few times the art was pixelated but I'm sure that'll be fixed. Some of it (art, map, UI) feels a bit overly busy. 
As far as content, UI, and fighting system, alot needs to be worked on. The fighting system is simple but shallow and there's two story missions along with a few side quests. I imagine over the next year (in which Behemoth works towards release) mechanics and story will be built upon. 
So if you're buying it now, know you're only going to get a few hours of enjoyment at first. But if you believe the track record of the Behemoth team and their wonderfully unique spirit, it's worth to get the game now and support the team!

29290069.review: I have nothing but respect for those at the Behemoth, one of the first indie studios out there, from alien hominid on ps2 to castle crashers to battleblock theater, the effort they put into their games stands out not just in quality but personality. The lineage for the company is one worth reading about, and If you're familiar with Newgrounds, you probably know the long history there,but these guys have been at their unique blend of game-spices since I was a wee lad, and it was a bootstraps effort to put the dream in motion and it wound them here on release of a hilarious fourth incarnation of a game only they can make and would be a pity to miss.  Unlike anything the Behemoth has done yet, the gameplay is layered, but easy to pick up, about as time consuming as you'd like it to be. The trailers speak for themselves, but the voicework from Stamper, the animation from Dan, the coding of a team that wrangles the madness together know what they are doing-if the early access tag has you 2spook'd. Cmon. It's the Behemoth, so for what I was anticipating, I was not at all let down. I say fifteen is a steal, and with all the art and animation and style and humor in here, you're not likely to find a game that has the kind of charm and wit with gameplay to match. Unique In short spurts or hours of competing for leaderboard rank, this hexa-brawly-turn-based strategy has more to offer than many out there of it's nature. As far as early access goes, this is tip top fare and well worth your $15.
